required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Beta-alanine Supplementation and Its Effects on Performance, Muscle Carnosine Content and Safety in Athletes With Spinal-cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock: Paralympians competing in wheelchair sports may experience a very high glycolytic demand (and therefore acidotic environment) in their upper-body muscles, particularly in high-intensity disciplines. Previous studies from our group have shown that upper-body exercise is very sensitive to the ergogenic effects of β-alanine supplementation and to other nutritional supplements capable of increasing buffering capacity. In line with this, have shown that upper-body muscle groups benefit more from artificially induced alkalosis than lower-body muscle groups. Although β-alanine appears to be an interesting and potential ergogenic supplement for paralympians, no study to date has assessed its potential in wheelchair athletes.In this study, we will evaluate the effects of β-alanine supplementation on upper-body performance in wheelchair athletes.

primary_outcome.description: Time to exhaustion test performed on arm crank ergometer

primary_outcome.measure: Muscle carnosine content before and after supplementation
primary_outcome.description: Assessed by muscle biopsy samples before performance tests

secondary_outcome.measure: Muscle carnosine content in trained (deltoid) vs. untrained (vastus lateralis) muscles
secondary_outcome.description: Deltoids microbiopsy and vastus lateralis biopsy

secondary_outcome.measure: Safety of beta-alanine supplementation measured by complete hemogram analysis

arm_group.description: 800 mg of dextrose, four times per day, during 28 days.
800 mg of beta-alanine, four times per day, during 28 days.

facility.name: School of Physical Education and Sports, University of Sao Paulo
